title: Mums share surprise delivery stories
text:
Use keywords to search content on this website Search Use keywords to search content on this website media_camera Mums Monique Jensen with bub Skylah-Rein, Brittany Ellis with son Kaizer, Kirsten Shepherd with son Gannon and NSW Ambulance’s Chris Lewis, Chris Farrell and Bianca Jackson. Picture: Justin Sanson Western Sydney mums meet up and share surprise delivery stories Danielle Jarvis, Mt Druitt-St Marys Standard March 28, 2017 4:12pm Ability Options nursery workers made redundant 
THREE western Sydney mums whose babies just could not wait have been reunited with the call-takers and paramedics who assisted them. 
The three families met at Tregear Ambulance Station today exactly a year after the babies were born and shared stories about the fast and frantic labours — one in the ambulance on the side of the road and the other two in their own homes. 
Between January 1 and December 31 last year, 71 western Sydney mothers delivered their babies out of hospital — including one in a McDonald’s carpark and another on Richmond Rd — and three of those births took place on the morning of March 28. media_camera Emerton's Brittany Ellis and her son Kaizer with paramedic Chris Farrell and partner Jason Martin. Picture: Justin Sanson. 
When Emerton mother of two, 23-year-old Brittany Ellis, was 38 weeks into her third pregnancy, she expected to have a hospital birth just like her other two. But at 2.10am on that fateful Saturday, she called triple 0 with intense contractions. 
“She met us at the door (of her home) and the way she was presenting we knew we had to get her there pretty quickly, but on the way things changed and we had to pull over and deliver there on the roadside,” NSW Ambulance officer Chris Farrell said. 
Just 20 minutes later, she gave birth to her third child, baby boy Kaizer, in the back of an ambulance on the side of Richmond Rd. 
“I just kept telling Kaizer ‘we did it, we did it’,” Ms Ellis said. 
Mr Farrell said it was rare for paramedics to deliver a baby. 
“It’s pretty rare — we get usually get to women in labour but it’s rare to actually deliver them,” he said. “That was the second time I had delivered and I’ve had one since, so three all up. I’ve been (a paramedic) for four years.” media_camera Penrith's Kirsten Shepherd and son Gannon with NSW Ambulance’s Bianca Jackson. Picture: Justin Sanson 
About one and half hours later, in Penrith, Kirsten Shepherd was at home with family when she woke up with painful contractions. 
“I put it off as Braxton Hicks because my contractions were irregular, so I was back and forth to the bathroom (between 4-7am),” she said. 
Little Gannon arrived at 7.13am — just before the ambulance arrived. 
Ambulance officer Bianca Jackson had been in the job for just 13 months, when she took Ms Shepherd’s call around 7am. 
“As soon as they say someone’s about to have a baby we get kind of excited cause it’s always a good thing,” Ms Jackson said. media_camera Whalan's Monique Jensen with daughter Shylah-Rain and NSW Ambulance’s Chris Lewis. Picture: Justin Sanson 
Meanwhile, 32-year-old Whalan mother Monique Jensen was at home when her labour with her fifth child, Shylah-Rain, was intensified. 
“I could feel contractions starting at 2am in the morning and they were reasonably early stages of labour,” Ms Jensen said. 
“About 9am I rang my mum. She came over and we rang the hospital at 10am and they said no you’re not ready yet you’ve got plenty of time. Call back at noon. She was born at 11.48am.” 
Ms Jensen was in her loungeroom surrounded by towels, pillows, her mother and neighbours and being watched by tradies who were renovating the house across the street. 
“My main worry was not having a doctor,” she said. “I was so worried if something went wrong. At 11.38am I made the call to the paramedics and she was born at 11.48am.” 
Call taker Chris Lewis said: “It was a real family and neighbourly affair. 
“I had a neighbour on the phone that I guided through the process and her sons did a great job getting stuff ready and waiting outside for the ambulance and bringing towels and a blanket. It progressed very very quickly. We don’t see them progress that quickly. 
“You never forget that first cry. I’ve delivered 13 babies and that’s what we’re straining to here over the phone because if you hear that all’s well.” media_camera Monique Jensen and Brittany Ellis swap stories with Chris Lewis and Chris Farrell at Tregear Reserve. Picture: Justin Sanson 
Despite all the commotion, Ms Jensen said the first thing she did after giving birth was thank her mum. 
“I feel my mum is champion. Even though I was the one in pain, the nervous wreck and pushing — I wouldn’t have known what to do if she wasn’t there.” 
Ambulance call-takers assisted a total of 142 of the 320 out of hospital births last year. Paramedics delivered 94 of those births while 23 mums gave birth on the side of the road, including 10 in an ambulance. 
Mr Lewis had one piece of advise for any mum who finds themselves in an out-of-hospital delivery situation. 
“Call us straight away. If you think there’s the remotest possibility there’s something happening. Don’t try to drive. If you’re in a car its much harder.”
